Problem:
Consider a system modelled by a second-order linear differential equation \\( \\ddot{x} + p \\dot{x} + qx = 0 \\), where p and q are constants. We introduce a Fourier transform of the displacement function \\( x(t) \\) to investigate its behavior in the frequency domain.

If, during observation, an additional damping term represented by function \\( d(t) = e^{-\\alpha t} \\) (where \\(\\alpha\\) is a constant) is introduced to the system, will the Fourier transform section corresponding to the new system represent only the effects of the original parameters p and q?
Explanation: The intervention with the damping term \\( d(t) \\) alters the system's dynamics significantly by adding an exponential decay factor \\( e^{-\\alpha t} \\). Accordingly, the frequency spectrum obtained from the Fourier transform will reflect the influences of \\(\\alpha\\) along with p and q, confusing the isolated effects of each parameter due to their interaction in the frequency domain.
